'Media Matters' Exposes Myths, Pens Open Letter to Media About Lies and Distortions on 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' - Towleroad, More than gay news. More gay men
 
 
 Some great work from Media Matters today in a posting detailing the Myths and Falsehoods on 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'. 
 
 Dadt Media Matters (with a coalition of groups and individuals) also penned a letter to the media advising them to be wary of distortions regarding the military gay ban and its repeal.
 
 Wrote MM:
 
 Don't Ask, Don't Tell proponents too often paint a distorted picture of what a repeal would mean. Today, Media Matters for America released a comprehensive review detailing how opinion pages and cable news talk shows have been flooded with falsehoods and anti-gay rhetoric to support the dubious argument that Don't Ask, Don't Tell is working.
 
 Myths that repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell would adversely affect unit cohesion, retention, or the HIV rate among servicemembers are not based in reality. Similarly, the anti-gay rhetoric permeating many of these arguments only serves to cheapen the national discussion on this important issue.
 
 Because news outlets continue to repeat these outrageous myths, a coalition of organizations is banding together to combat misinformation about the Don't Ask, Don't Tell law. As Congress moves forward on this legislation, we will be vigilant in ensuring that news reports are accurate and fair. The public deserves an honest debate -- not one marred by blatant falsehoods and anti-gay attacks.

 Alright--good points. I'm impressed that you're looking at the fiscal costs of these matters: an issue often neglected.
 Let's also think, for a moment, about the fiscal, cohesive, and morale issues if the "don't ask" part of the policy is removed. (Which it will be if DADT is rescinded). Personnel could then ask "are you gay" with no repercussions that I know of. Then there is the stress of servicepeople knowing there are homosexual servicepeople in their barracks, showers, etc., as well as who they are, and that these homosexual men and women may be attracted to them. There is the potential for serious issues there. 
 Then there is the problem of homophobic commanding officers who would now be able to ask directly if a service person is gay, in front of their peers, I might add. 
 There are some real potential problems here that need to at least be addressed before this policy is just pulled willy-nilly.

There's been a lot in media (often stories first reported in political special interest media 'outlets') specifying various high ranking military personnel supporting the repeal of DADT.
 
 Here is one who does not, as both sides of this issue need to be reported.
 
 Top US Marine rejects Obama plan to repeal gay ban
 
 "The head of the US Marines said on Thursday he opposed ending the ban on gays serving openly in the military, the first top officer to break openly with President Barack Obama over the issue.
 
 General James Conway told the Senate Armed Services Committee that he disagreed with Obama's plan to repeal the ban.
 
 "My best military advice to this committee, to the (defense) secretary, and to the president would be to keep the law such as it is."
 
 Conway said the current policy worked and any bid to lift the ban should answer the question: "do we somehow enhance the war fighting capabilities of the United States Marine Corps by allowing homosexuals to openly serve?"
 
 Conway's public rejection of his commander-in-chief's stance is sure to fuel debate in Congress on the issue and reflects apprehension among some senior military officers about changing the 1993 law.
 
 The chiefs of the US Army and Air Force also expressed doubts about lifting the ban at congressional hearings this week, saying they were concerned about putting the military under further strain in the midst of two wars."
